segments.en: Linked Discourses 7
2. Lay Followers
11. With Bhāradvāja the Farmer
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā magadhesu viharati dakkhiṇāgirismiṃ ekanāḷāyaṃ brāhmaṇagāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Magadhans in the Southern Hills near the brahmin village of Ekanāḷa.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa pañcamattāni naṅgalasatāni payuttāni honti vappakāle.
segments.en: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer had harnessed around five hundred plows, it being the season for sowing.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa kammanto tenupasaṅkami.
segments.en: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to where Bhāradvāja the Farmer was working.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena kasibhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa parivesanā vattati.
segments.en: Now at that time Bhāradvāja the Farmer was distributing food.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā yena parivesanā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
segments.en: Then the Buddha went to where the distribution was taking place and stood to one side.

segments.pli: Addasā kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ piṇḍāya ṭhitaṃ.
segments.en: Bhāradvāja the Farmer saw him standing for alms
and said to him,

segments.pli: “ahaṃ kho, samaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmi.
segments.en: “I plough and sow, ascetic, and then I eat.

segments.pli: Tvampi, samaṇa, kasassu ca vapassu ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjassū”ti.
segments.en: You too should plough and sow, then you may eat.”

segments.pli: “Ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī”ti.
segments.en: “I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.”

segments.pli: “Na kho mayaṃ passāma bhoto gotamassa yugaṃ vā naṅgalaṃ vā phālaṃ vā pācanaṃ vā balībadde vā, atha ca pana bhavaṃ gotamo evamāha:
segments.en: “I don’t see Master Gotama with a yoke or plow or plowshare or goad or oxen, yet he says:

segments.pli: ‘ahampi kho, brāhmaṇa, kasāmi ca vapāmi ca, kasitvā ca vapitvā ca bhuñjāmī’”ti.
segments.en: ‘I too plough and sow, brahmin, and then I eat.’”

segments.pli: Atha kho kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then Bhāradvāja the Farmer addressed the Buddha in verse:
“You claim to be a farmer,
but I don’t see your plough.
If you’re a farmer, declare to me:
how are we to understand your farming?”
“Faith is my seed, austerity my rain,
and wisdom is my yoke and plough.
Conscience is my pole, mind my strap,
mindfulness my plowshare and goad.
Guarded in body and speech,
I restrict my intake of food.
I use truth as my scythe,
and gentleness is my release.
Energy is my beast of burden,
transporting me to a place of sanctuary.
It goes without turning back
to the place where there is no sorrow.
That’s how to do the farming
that has the Deathless as its fruit.
When you finish this farming
you’re released from all suffering.”
“Eat, Master Gotama,
you are truly a farmer.

segments.pli: Yañhi bhavaṃ gotamo amatapphalampi kasiṃ kasatī”ti.
segments.en: For Master Gotama does the farming that has the Deathless as its fruit.”
“Food enchanted by a spell isn’t fit for me to eat.
That’s not the way of those who see, brahmin.
The Buddhas reject things enchanted with spells.
Since nature is real, brahmin, that’s how they live.
Serve with other food and drink
the consummate one, the great hermit,
with defilements ended and remorse stilled.
For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

segments.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kasibhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: When he had spoken, the brahmin Bhāradvāja the Farmer said to the Buddha,
“Excellent, Master Gotama …
From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

suttaplex.blurb: A brahmin farmer criticizes the Buddha for failing to produce food, merely living off the work of others. But the Buddha shows that his true work is spiritual.
